body: While Coach Jim Boyle of St. Joseph's, one of the four teams in the E.C.A.C. Holiday Festival that begins tonight at Madison Square Garden, was discussing his starting lineup at a luncheon yesterday, Chris Mullin paid little attention. Instead, Mullin, the high-scoring St. John's guard, was studying the Brigham Young basketball brochure. St. John's
title: MULLIN IS STUDENT OF HIS GAME

body: Two suspects in the slaying of a Housing Authority police officer in Brooklyn 10 months ago were arrested yesterday after the police received a tip from a man charged with grand larceny, detectives said. The officer, James Carragher, 56 years old, was fatally wounded in a robbery near his apartment in the Flatlands section of Brooklyn on Feb. 11
title: Tip Leads to 2 Arrests In Slaying of an Officer

body: THERE is nothing circuitous about Flatbush Avenue. It cuts a long and almost direct swath through thec enter of Brooklyn from the Manhattan Bridge to the Belt Parkway. A long the way, it passes neighborhoods that have been in flux for d ecades. Change in neighborhoods and change in regional shopping patterns lead to evolution in the commercial life
title: FLATBUSH AVENUE TAKES ON NEW IDENTITY

body: A judge yesterday ordered a rerun next Tuesday of two disputed Democratic primary races in Brooklyn - one for the House of Representatives and one for the State Assembly - after charges of voting fraud. The order for the two reruns, which was given by Acting Justice Eugene Berkowitz of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, threw out the Sept. 23
title: RERUNS ORDERED IN BROOKLYN FOR TWO DISPUTED ELECTIONS

body: The New York City Health Department cited 36 food establishments last week for violations of the city's health code. In addition, it named seven restaurants that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations, and three that were closed after failure to do so. VIOLATIONS Candle Bar, 309 Amsterdam Ave. Mike's Pizza, 2038 Amsterdam Ave.
title: 36 Food Places Listed For Health Violations

title: CITY VOTE FOR TOP STATE OFFICES BY ASSEMBLY DISTRICTS; DEMOCRATIC REPUBLICAN GOVERNOR GOVERNOR

body: The New York City Department of Health cited 15 food establishments last week for violations of the health code. In addition, the department named eight that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations and four that were closed for failure to do so. VIOLATIONS Raccoon Lodge, 59 Warren St. Weitzman's Delicatessen, 102 Delancey St.
title: FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS CITTED FOR VIOLATIONS OF CITY HEALTH CODE

body: Competition among minority-group candidates could jeopardize the election of blacks in two Brooklyn Congressional districts that were redrawn to help their candidacies, according to some politicians. They say that black and Hispanic leaders should join in an effort to insure that the seats, in the new 11th and 12th Districts, are not lost to white
title: MINORITY DIVISIVENESS SEEN IN BROOKLYN RACES

body: A recent dispute over the appointment of a principal for a Brooklyn elementary school has focused attention on the process of selecting local school administrators under the city's decentralized school system. The naming of Kathleen Shay, a 34-year-old administrator of a remedial-school program, to be principal of Public School 193 in the Midwood
title: PARENTS' ROLE IN HIRING OF PRINCIPAL DISPUTED

body: Two men were arrested in New York City yesterday on charges of conspiring to purchase and export weapons and munitions, including surface-to-air missiles, for use by the Provisional Irish Republican Army in Northern Ireland, Federal authorities said. Two other men were seized in the city, and a third was being sought, in connection with another
title: F.B.I. IN CITY ARRESTS 4 IN PLOTS TO EXPORT ARMS TO I.R.A. UNITS

body: The City Planning Commission voted unanimously yesterday to clear the way for a private company to build a satellite communications center in a depressed section of Brooklyn. Construction of the proposed center - the Galaxy Satellite Station - is scheduled to begin this August in Brooklyn's East New York section on a vacant lot in the Spring Creek
title: PLANNING PANEL GIVES APPROVAL ON SATELLITE SITE

body: MARILYN PICKETT's children asked her to relay instructions to Al Arbour on Sunday night. They wanted the Islanders' coach to rest his best players so that the team would lose and have to play a fifth game back home on Long Island. Mrs. Pickett, whose husband, John, is the principal owner of the Islanders, had the feeling that Arbour and his players
title: Sports of The Times; Stanley Cup Is Back Home

body: National Historic Preservation Week begins today and 3,000 events are planned across the country to mark it. But in New York City, where preservation is a hotly debated topic, the celebration will be definitely low-key. According to the Landmarks Preservation Commission, there will be only two local manifestations. Next weekend, the Preservation
title: POSTINGS; PAST'S PRESENTS

body: They crowded onto the plastic chairs on the second floor of the old Municipal Building in Brooklyn yesterday, clutching slips of paper with the block and lot numbers of their properties. They were homeowners, and they wanted to get something back from the city. The owners were waiting their turns to come before a city tax commissioner to tell him
title: BESIEGED HOMEOWNERS APPEAL ON ASSESSMENTS

body: Federal agents said yesterday that they had seized 115 1/2 pounds of heroin that had been smuggled into the United States from Italy in elaborate espresso machines. They estimated the street value of the drug to be $70 million. William von Raab, the Commissioner of the United States Customs Service, who announced the seizure, said that it was
title: HEROIN VALUED AT $70 MILLION REPORTED SEIZED

body: PARKS are one of the few places where city dwellers can get a real sense of the seasonal changes that once directed human life. Most people seem to prefer to witness winter from behind a steamy apartment window. The parks seem deserted then, with only a few dog walkers and joggers to witness their bleak beauty and new serenity. But this Sunday,
title: SUNDAY WALK TO SCALE HEIGHTS OF PROSPECT PARK

body: Two men were stabbed and shotgunned to death early yesterday morning in a Greenwich Village apartment in what the police described as a drug dispute. Two men and a 15-year-old youth were arrested near the address and charged with the murders. According to the police, the two victims, identified as Kip Brookstool, 27 years old, and Gregory Beckert,
title: 2 Men Slain on W. 10th St.; 3 Suspects Arrested Nearby

body: A 17-year-old Brooklyn youth was arrested yesterday afternoon and charged with shooting an off-duty detective who was lured into a trap set for a good Samaritan in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn on Dec. 31, the police said. The detective, George Owen, 53, was driving alone at 2:45 A.M. on Eastern Parkway toward his Nassau County home
title: Boy, 17, Is Seized in Shooting Of Detective Lured Into Trap
